newsitem.title: BELARUS: Russia '96 oil supply via Belarus rises to 62 mln.
newsitem.headline: Russia '96 oil supply via Belarus rises to 62 mln.

text.p: Belarus' section of the Druzhba oil pipeline, which transports Russian supplies to Germany and Poland, carried 62.2 million tonnes of oil last year compared to 57.0 million in 1995, an energy official said on Monday.

The official, from state-owned concern Belnefteproduct, told Reuters that Belarus increased its volumes along its stretch of the Druzhba, or Friendship, link because it was eager to cash in on a boom in world oil prices.
"Increased exports last year were linked to higher prices for oil in Europe," said the official, who asked not to be named.

"Belarus could send more oil to the West through its territory," he said, adding that the link was still working at only about half of its capacity. "But it's first and foremost up to the Russian oil exporters."
The official said Russia sold 12.0 million tonnes of oil to the former Soviet republic for refining domestically last year. The figure is in addition to the Druzhba export figures.
The Druzhba link has been under-utilised since the 1991 breakup of the former Soviet Union, when many European clients diversified their energy supplies or simply lacked the cash.
